@alias_petrichor @GilaRPGs My relationship to RQ is complex. I've listened to the entirety of The Magnus Archives at least a half dozen times and probably more. It is a crowning achievement in horror fiction. But I've never been able to get into RQG.
@gatlingxyz This is honestly my preferred method of AP delivery, for what it’s worth.

@friede Personally - and these are absolutely my research interests and not necessarily your own - the questions that are most on my mind are how do APs below the biggest handful affect sales of smaller games and how do they change long term behavior of players Re: adopting new games.
@friede Honestly your work is some of the best stuff we have so far looking critically at APs so I wouldn’t be too hard on yourself :P

@PartyOfOnePod Like what I’d love from Fred - but have no real expectation of it because the labor is absolutely not worth it for them - is to check against the top twenty next largest APs of their games and see what the average and mean impacts are on sales.

@PartyOfOnePod Still, if we could get show creators to ask this question (and others) frequently and reliably, and most usefully to featured designers who can actually check their sales figures… well I think that’s the goal. So I do appreciate you starting it.

@PartyOfOnePod And unfortunately I think that’s a big part of why my initial tweets got both so much support and so much backlash. Absent good data I’m either confirming someone’s bias or outright attacking them, with no real counterpoint other than “You’re good//You’re bad for this opinion.”

@PartyOfOnePod Yeah I think anecdotal data is really useful as we aggregate more of it, so I appreciate you posing this question to your followers. But I’m always highly suspect of them. You always have vast overreporting of outliers, both positive and negative. That lends itself to opinion.
Does anyone have favorite blog posts interpreting Soulsborne games through the lens of TTRPGs (and I guess specifically older//OSR play//dungeon design)?

@major_tmrw @will_jobst If we could get that going it would be at least a step toward something bigger and more robust. It would help us figure out how we’d want to gather and sort data moving forward and might prompt us to figure out what kinds of questions we need to be asking. From 0 to that is huge.
And on that note I’m gonna put my phone away and cuddle my dog. Goodnight.

If we could conclusively establish that APs really increase sales and the conditions under which they best did that, we’d put to rest an endless shitfight and probably help out a TON of game designers and show creators in the process. I’m not the guy to do it. Somebody should.
RT @fussybabybitch: It’s called 101 Cigarette Tea

Anyway, this is my mea culpa of sorts for doing a bad discourse. I’m sorry I expressed myself poorly and it led to hurting both people I know and people I do not. But more than that I’m sorry we’re going to wake up tomorrow into the exact same cycle borne of not having much data.
@GilaRPGs I also TOTALLY buy this but I wish I had data to firm it up

@will_jobst Okay so yeah, immediately my suspicion of a couple primary differences is confirmed by Fred, the biggest being long campaigns versus one-shot or short features probably makes the biggest difference. This is good to have. Thanks, Will <3

@JohanNohr Totally. I don’t think it does hurt. That would be… incredibly weird. But not hurting and as a generalization being wildly beneficial are completely different. I’d like good data to figure out degree of impact.

The companies who make these reports have industry data access that frankly should give people genuine pause and even they can’t dig up more than speculation about almost anything. It’s all proxy data and extrapolation from boardgames and retail game cafe sales and such.

As is true of so Goddamn much in TTRPGs, we have SHOCKINGLY poor data and run off beliefs and rumors as though they were fact. You’d be hard pressed to get good data on even WotC. I say this as someone who has access to industry reports that can cost upwards of $10,000.

Furthermore I’m very interested to know if anyone has attempted to verify the claim that having your game on an AP translates to substantially increased sales in general. From what I’ve heard from designers, even the biggest shows don’t move the needle all that much for long.

I’m not gonna back down on the point of APs being wildly popular and financially successful beyond the games played on them in basically every case other than a handful of the largest games. This is pretty easily established beyond anecdotes and I don’t know who’d contest it.

Hey here’s the deal: I stand by my general dislike of APs after having listened to quite a good number of them over the years. I’ve tried and tried and tried. I’m convinced there’s something there for people in general but not for me. But I expressed it inelegantly. That’s on me.

@LuchaLibris Like at this point I’m totally fine to roll on the rest of it as “You can’t express an opinion in a way that’s insufficiently nuanced on Twitter” and mostly I’m both in agreement with that and okay with it. But you’ve got a pretty big claim in there that I’m not seeing backed up.

@LuchaLibris Yeah that’s true. I’m happy to very publicly agree that you’re correct on it. Still would love to see numbers of the marginalization of smaller creators. Because I’m not gonna just accept that point on faith.
@LuchaLibris So what I’m asking is, as someone who is undeniably more plugged in than me, do you know where we could settle this?

@LuchaLibris No I absolutely am aware that many are making shows. It’s difficult, frankly, to be online in the indie games space in any way and not know. I’d argue you have to go out of your way to limit what you see to be unaware. But their presence in no way speaks to their majority.

@LuchaLibris There are a whole lot of people who make deeply mediocre APs for themselves who aren’t financially or otherwise marginalized. I’d perhaps to go so far as to claim that based on other spaces where we have more rigorous data, they likely outnumber the marginalized creators.

@LuchaLibris Do marginalized creators make smaller shows and can what I say be really fucked up as it regards those people? Totally. That’s really fucked of me. But it seems both factually wrong and morally incorrect to generalize out to all smaller creators from that.

@LuchaLibris Honestly? You’re right on enough points here that I’m not gonna come back or be snarky. There are absolutely things I said that could be read as or are outright fucked up. That’s on me. But I dont think it’s right to claim the backgrounds of smaller creators without evidence.

@s_m_i Honestly same. I wish no ill to any creator for their chosen medium, other than maybe when it destroys the world, but I don’t want something hampered by intrinsic but unnecessary flaws to become standardized. It only hurts the future.
@LuchaLibris Wait so which one is it? https://t.co/xufeC9ElYv
@s_m_i And like maybe after we get designers making specifically Y for a good while we can finally get Z and nail both in one.

@s_m_i I personally can’t wait for a future where enough people who start in APs take the leap into designing their own games that better suit the medium and it can grow into what I imagine most people who enjoy it see it like now.
RT @snurgle_: i can't believe they fucking milked him. https://t.co/ugKAj0cwwz

@s_m_i Absolutely. I think talented people are out there on both sides. I think if anything they’re hamstrung by games that don’t actually play to their strengths. Like what if improv groups could only work off Ibsen? You’d expect similar results. A few geniuses. Mostly struggles.

@Sharessan @JennytheZen1 Yeah like what if APs but we then went and transcribed them and punched up the language so it flows well and stayed cohesive and we could consciously inject asides for teaching purposes without breaking the narrative flow? They’re basically my ideal

@PartyOfOnePod For what it’s worth, I have never consciously considered Party of One an AP. It’s always been an interview show done over a game to me. But if I am to frame it as an AP in my mind it’s probably the thing that makes me most want to retract my argument.
@JennytheZen1 @Sharessan Literally one of the things I mention elsewhere in the comments :P

@PartyOfOnePod Here’s the thing, bud. I think what makes your work best is what distinguishes it most from the majority of APs: two people have inherently tighter control of a narrative than a big group and often far better rapport. You found a solution to a problem people weren’t even naming.

@rnlanders Hahaha okay yeah definitely not the case but I can see the misunderstanding now :P
@rnlanders But I’m thinking you’d have like a .1-.2 correlation between “general skill at narrative writing” and “GMing quality by player self-report of satisfaction.”

@rnlanders The one exception might be between specifically writers on things like MUDs and play-by-post forums, but that’s a very specific kind of writing disconnected from how we perceive that skill otherwise.

@rnlanders In terms of correlations, I’d say there’s a weak one between effective GMing and effective writing, much weaker than between GMing and something like sketch comedy or even young adult education. But we imagine it’s a strong correlation because we popularly misunderstand GMing.

@rnlanders I’d say the one exception might be a writers room in something like a comedy show with a very fast writing schedule, where you’re just throwing shit at the wall, riffing off other people, and putting it together quickly. Like SNL could be a good comparison.
@rnlanders Lore writers would probably make valuable additions to a writers room, but most people in a writers room wouldn’t be good GMs.

@rnlanders A common misperception of GMing in practice. Like think of a GM who kept to their incredibly built out lore at the expense of the players’ joy. They’d be an awful GM even if they’d created a brilliantly engaging world. For campaign play sure you do need it, but minute to minute?

@rnlanders Hrmmm game writer can mean so many things so a bit of clarity would be useful. Writer as in designer? No, not necessarily. Understanding relationships between mechanics doesn’t necessarily go hand-in-hand with improvisation and showmanship. Writer as worldbuilder? Maybe a bit.

There will always be outliers and whole segments of the space where the above doesn’t make too much difference. For instance, I have no problem believing that someone who masters overlay design and dramatic tension could make an excellent solitaire game with minimal mechanics.

Just because TTRPGs aren’t videogames and don’t require hard technical skills to produce in the same way doesn’t mean there aren’t still hard skills required to make them pretty good, at least as concerns the games that most of the market by volume plays.

Here’s an opinion that might make some people upset: the skills required to be a good streamer or game master and distinct from the skills required to be a good game designer and you shouldn’t hire people good at the former to do the latter based purely on their audience size.

@Halleyspilot So fantasy heartbreaker is a fraught term but in short it’s the idea of a fantasy game that’s basically someone’s passion project but in the end is fundamentally a riff on something earlier. There’s a bit more than that (e.g. it’s not a retroclone), but that’s the core.

@SaveVsTPK T&T and RQ are both far too early to be considered fantasy heartbreakers in my book and also have a generative process beyond calling back to something else, and BW is absolutely it’s own beast.

@SpindriftGames @SebEless The crowdfunding is for three things:

1) Pay a digital preservation specialist to create a comprehensive taxonomy and tagging system
2) Begin the vast cataloguing work inputing 50+ years of TTRPG output, much that’s currently in no archive system anywhere
3) University outreach

@SebEless But you’re right on an important component being getting books into libraries, which is why I’ve already started and will continue to develop a distribution network through independent distributors to get games into collections.

@SebEless From experience helping set up the games libraries of several major schools in New York and Texas, as well as the Austin Public Library system, this is not accurate. The standards they create internally are vastly different and often inadequate for a comprehensive system.

Anyway this is why I fully expect every mid-to-large company in the world to get on NFTs before they finally crash and destroy a huge number of foolish investors. Because the above is a financing wet dream if you care about earnings above all else, like we incentivize.

Like this whole thing is basically “what if a penny stock boiler room scheme” but on steroids and with a shiny new coat and if you treat it as such then okay, you’re not a good person, but you’re also correctly identifying a good way to get rich quickly through bad means.
Oh also they seem to be an effective money laundering mechanism. Really if you’re pro criminality without feeling any need to add prosociality, they seem fine as a substrate on which to grow grift.

One thing I’ll give NFTs: if you need capital and prefer to take it from people with no sense of an object’s value (who can essentially be fleeced consequence free) instead of from institutions that will demand it back (likely with interest), it is an attractive funding source.

@nerdahedron @comerpatrick @Gripnr Yeah either this is asked in bad faith or stems from, again, what I can only describe as a stunning lack of understanding of the core consumer base to whom you’re appealing. The above is the prevailing sentiment and it is easily found.

@comerpatrick @nerdahedron @Gripnr I would be genuinely fascinated to see this research as I’ve seen internal market research from multiple large firms that contradicts your findings, in addition to the intense vocal outcry from multiple segments of the overall analog games community.

@nerdahedron @comerpatrick @Gripnr Case in point, there has been a large scale exodus from Kickstarter, a business integral to the livelihoods of groups small and large throughout the industry, based purely on the investigation of crypto and blockchain tech. NFTs are substantially more reviled.
@comerpatrick @nerdahedron @Gripnr Sorry, that’s in the following tweet.

@nerdahedron @comerpatrick @Gripnr So how to make it better? Honestly? Either pivot away from this space completely or fold and regroup with what remains of your capital to do some extremely needed market research. Right now, you have an essentially non-starter idea from a community adoption standpoint.

@nerdahedron @comerpatrick @Gripnr I genuinely do not think there is a single media environment in the world less predisposed to the use and even existence of NFTs than analog games, especially TTRPGs, and you would need to do the equivalent of solving cancer and world hunger to get a non-hostile audience.

@nerdahedron @comerpatrick @Gripnr In addition to this, even if you were to somehow find a practical use for NFTs that couldn’t be handled by other technologies, you’re pitched to a space inherently poisoned on the core difference of your offering. It shows a stunning and profound lack of market insight.

@TheOtherTracy And like that bleed isn’t necessarily a bad thing from a design or play standpoint, but it makes my primary engagement with the space much more complicated when we’re already still extremely bad at it without this new complication.

@TheOtherTracy I think the reasons I personally dislike the trend are quirks of my own engagement with the hobby as an archivist and collector much more so than a designer, educator, or even player. But beyond that it quickly starts bleeding the territory between TTRPGs, cRPGs, and VNs.

@TheOtherTracy I can’t speak to what exactly Oz meant in his original tweet but for me it’s the growing trend of using web tech to skip printing and more static digital formats, which to me is both an interesting development and an entirely new skill set added into the pool needed to make RPGs.
Anyway I’ve been surprised by things I didn’t think I’d like before so I’m ready for that to happen here. Hasn’t yet, but past experience tells me it will if I keep an open enough mind.

@momatoes Otherwise that’s really it. Is it specifically, intentionally regarding analog play (rather than something that wasn’t intended as such but can be used that way, which could be almost literally any object or media)? Was it released in the correct timeframe? If yes, eligible. 3/3

@momatoes As for format, so long as it is easily distributable it can be anything but I’m drawing a rough line at things that are fully playable as videogames. I say rough because there isn’t any hard distinction at the edges of analog and digital games, not really. 2/2

@momatoes Great questions! For judging purposes I’d say English is best, but I’m not limiting it to that. What I’ll say is I can’t ensure another language will be known by one or more of the judges, so if it’s not in English we may have to judge it on aesthetics alone. 1/2
@JNButlerArt Obviously that’s a very blurry line but if you feel you can make a case for it then totally shoot your shot :)

@JNButlerArt It’s a very good question and one I haven’t entirely nailed down. Where I am currently is that anything intended for play or about play is eligible. So that’s games, articles, and paraphernalia. If the art is a play-aid I’d say yeah, but if it’s art disconnect from play no.

That's it for now. I may add to this thread as more questions are asked. But those are the primary notes that have come up in discussing the process so far. Let me know your thoughts! This is an experiment. I want further research directions for next year. https://t.co/6nPbzsdRHL

Third: Judges will become away of the identities of the other Judges at the end of the process, likely one month before winners are announced but after they are decided. This is to give time to write longform critique, analysis, and personal stories about games of their choosing.

Second: Judges will not know who other Judges are. I'm even going to be writing up an NDA that will last until the results are announced. This is a private endeavor. If you want to judge it is not for clout. It is because you want to help build a new critical process in TTRPGs.

First: I am not The Judge. If anything, it might be best to consider me The Coordinator. I'll be putting in my input but it will be the same as for every other judge: anonymized, equally weighted, done through a three-step quantitative process. I merely collate and analyze.

@DungeonsOnADime Again, with the caveat that we need to be clearer in what we mean and ideally conduct a large series of experiments validating what degree of “trust” on such a scale would best correspond with what levels of expertise to facilitate effective learning.

@DungeonsOnADime Oh again I disagree but now we’re getting deep into “not able to be communicated over Twitter” territory. Like this is a good deal of learning design assessment work right here. It’s by no means meant to gatekeep, and is pretty fundamental to effective instruction.

@DungeonsOnADime But I do take your point that even so, we need to be more rigorous in both establishing what is meant by the poles on a scale of trust and also what is implied by a title being placed at a certain point. I think it's possible. But there does need to be much more clarity.

@DungeonsOnADime We see this in all sorts of ways. Pain, for instance, is not an easily quantified thing. Hence why we still use the smiley to frowny face scales. Goodwill is another. Lots of extremely important assessments have basically no solid quantitative backing.

@DungeonsOnADime Okay so I agree with almost everything in the thread except part five. Much assessment isn't objective measurement. Like... my field wouldn't exist if that were the case. It is often finding ways to quantify qualitative data to give a rough sense of something.

@DungeonsOnADime Not to cut in mid-thread but that's what I've been waiting to say. It's a bit like arguing adding an easy difficulty mode alongside the intended difficulty is somehow insulting to players. Clearly no. Supportive and accessible options are if anything high trust.

@Rule42Arts Yeah I'll keep considering it as more dissention comes in but I think this is a case of the emotional qualia we attach to a word outside of its strict meaning getting in the way of understanding how well the word does indeed describe the perspective.

@fuseboy I think there can be but it's still a spectrum to me. TotSK is absolutely low trust to me but how introductory textbooks ought to be. You don't immediately give raw primary source material to someone who doesn't know how to work with it. It's rightfully and justifiably low trust.

@DungeonsOnADime Would you mind explaining the gate-keepy bit? It's odd to me because I don't see low or high trust as inherently pejorative. It would be like saying an intro textbook is worse than an academic paper. They're just for different audiences and purposes.

Considering an assessment scale for modules that runs from Low Trust to High Trust. Been feeling like that’s one of the elements missing from how we talk about them. Like, how much does the author trust the GM to run this without training wheels?

Just want to quickly shout out @TheDungeonCoach. It's always nice when someone reaches out to you because they admire your work and want to use it, but when they go the extra step to work with you on adapting it and actually accept your feedback... *Chef kiss*

@brickk @AWiseArtist I certainly would, too. That’s the end goal for me :) I’m just realistic about us needing to start somewhere, and hopeful we don’t tear those first few people to shreds before the next few get brave enough to try and do better.

@brickk @AWiseArtist And I don’t think it’s something you necessarily need to do, either. But I think it’s something that has value within a given medium, that isn’t dependent on being a working practitioner, and that enriches an overall space even when it doesn’t directly help artists :)
@OhMyMithrandir Fuck yeah love that for you, Kate

@brickk @AWiseArtist Honestly, I think that unfairly demeans both your work and pop music. Pop has a profound impact on our lives and the world at large. There’s no reason yours can’t, too. But it is good to have an idea of how it might so you don’t influence the world in unintended ways.

@brickk @AWiseArtist It’s about where the work is situated within a given space, within society, how it is informed by not only other works within the medium but from without. It’s a much more holistic conceptualization of the work and how it fits into our lives. It’s not just about making it better.

@brickk @AWiseArtist I think this is a common feeling among people who produce work within their given field, but I think is misunderstands the purpose of Criticism. Feedback should absolutely be from people who have done the work. But criticism as I see it is bigger, broader 1/
RT @epistemophagy: But the same people absolutely will loftily tell you "you can't just reject [x] because you don't like it, you have to p…

@SaveVsTPK Well lazy complaints are never really good critiques, period, except maybe in aggregate and I don’t know of anyone out here doing big data analytics on casual complaints about WotC. More interesting question might be “Why are there so many lazy complaints instead of critiques?”

@brickk @AWiseArtist I don’t disagree with your assessment of the reality of the situation. I just think it’s deeply tragic and the only way it will change is because some people choose to take enough fire to normalize it. Not that I can ask anyone to do so. But I don’t see it happening otherwise.
@AWiseArtist @brickk As has been my line for a long time, you cannot have a rich critical tradition if your only critics are also working professionals.

@AWiseArtist @brickk I do think we have fostered a culture in analog games - CCGs and boardgames are if anything even more hostile to critique - that is substantially worse than in many more mature media, but I also think that has a lot to do with almost everyone being a creator here.

@Tabletophoard At this point I almost only use system agnostic ones. The one case where I prefer statted, system-specific modules is when I’m learning a new system. Once I’ve gotten the system’s basics, that stuff just breaks my reading flow when I’m trying to get a grasp on the module.

If you don’t have physical copies to donate or simply don’t find the idea appealing, no harm no foul. I will not hold it against you. It will not affect how The Awards proceed. The judges won’t even know who gave physical copies. But some students somewhere will.

So part of The Awards is this little attempt to put together a package each year that a university can put into their collection for students to examine and play with. That might be at a games studies program. It might be in regular circulation . But I want to get it out there.

As I’ve worked with various organizations to help build out their TTRPG collections, one thing has consistently occurred to me: even when people are hype on the idea their knowledge rarely extends beyond the most trad. Their not against it. They just don’t know anything else.

One of my many gripes is information accessibility in TTRPGs is often even worse than physical accessibility, but we largely ignore the first in the Discourse because our being part of it pretty much assumes we’ve already conquered the problem for ourselves.

Because it’s come up a few times and my website is still crap:

Physical copies are not required. I am judging based off digital alone. However! If you have physical copies I will happily accept them. All copies sent in will be donated to a university with a games collection. https://t.co/yf1MqrUya7

These tweets brought to you by yet another conversation with a friend who is shocked someone very visibly the face of a positive trend is also an absolute shark. I seem to have these conversations quarterly at this point.

If you manage to accomplish something that nobody else thinks is possible, especially if you are in some way systemically oppressed, you likely have a near psychopathic dedication to success and keeping the position you've attained. You don't get there otherwise.

Here's a basic assumption that's served me pretty well in life: assume the first few people to accomplish anything big and new are so ruthless they'd kill you as soon as look at you. If someone is a "first," steer clear.

My imagination is frankly very limited but I’m surrounded by people who are endless fonts of it, and all I want is for them to spend as many hours as is humanly possible making stuff that is strange and full of oddness for money that lets them live comfortably.

It’s super selfish. I don’t really care if the world is better. I’m pretty sure we’re all gonna die like pretty damn soon. But I want as much weird art in my life before I go. That’s where I’m at these days.
Just “Here’s $50,000 let’s play Mad Libs and then you make it, okay?”

You know why I actually want a lot of money? Because I want to pay other people with it. I want to take underpaid writers, artists, layout people, book binders, and all sorts of other artsy folks who make things I can barely imagine and go “Dragons but it’s Gundam” and pay them.

@Pandatheist Haha again I think this is a good hour-long conversation for us to record :P But yeah, I don’t disagree. I just think we shouldn’t minimize how much knowledge of both what tools exist and how to employ them is still a very real form of tech debt we need to overcome.
@Pandatheist No but we still need to do our interview (I’ve been so fucking bad about those this year) so let’s save it for then.

@Jesseabe This has also broadly been my experience with CoG but V:NR does a very good job drip feeding you rules when you have rules transparency turned on (you can still play with them not displayed for individual choices but I find that has less teaching utility).

@Pandatheist I mean I fucking love those games but I think they run into the same problem as extremely professional APs: they set an unrealistically high bar for what content needs to look like. But if you’ve got the team and the capital to make it work, fuck yeah do it.

And because multiple people have now asked where they can look at an example of this that I believe is done very well, go check out Vampire: Night Road. It’s by a small indie designer and as far as I can tell doesn’t put money directly in the pocket of WW (if that’s an issue).
@goatmansgoblet If you buy it and aren’t happy I’ll just Venmo you $10 to make it up to you.

But if you got a solid designer to work with a halfway decent fic writer and someone who can make Twine work pretty okay, I think you’d have a product that could increase game sales more than you can believe. Like that’s where your excess crowdfunding dollars should go.
@goatmansgoblet Honestly if you made the content I’d help you implement it.
@Jesseabe Vampire: Night Road has become my primary recommendation to get people thinking about it seriously.

The main caveat is how categorically poor teachers we are with some notable exceptions. But a benefit of teaching through IF rather than normal instructional methods is that people will still learn if your narrative is sufficiently good, and we’re real good at the narrative bit.

I’ve put this another way before which is that if TTRPG designers started working with things like Twine to make IF, we’d just corner that market. But it also holds that this being true means that we already have the core skillset to really knock instructional IF out of the park.

Stop making videos or at least rely on them less. They’re incredibly passive content that don’t actually encourage people to learn rules deeply enough to apply them in an active play experience and either set unrealistic standards for how play looks or are not engaging viewing.
@MxMstrH Dude right now, literally this moment, go buy Vampire: Night Road on your phone. Hit me up in a couple days to thank me.

I have now had multiple non-TTRPG people learn the rules to a game through interactive fiction they’ve played on their phone, gotten a sense of the narrative experience, the tone of the world, and desperately want more. They’ve actively converted through guided solo play.

Okay hot take (maybe): a lot of TTRPG folks have this animosity toward video games that try to explicitly replicate our play experience, but I genuinely think interactive fiction is the best thing created yet to teach RPGs and get more people both playing and buying the products.

And they went and Goddamn made it fully years before the gestalt indie design world decided those there things they really wanted. We were still deep in the “Metatopia is like a handful of LARPs and a billion PbtA clones” days when City of Mist released.
@ZapDynamic Truly. Such good art and art direction.

You want tag-based PbtA? You want to use the basic structures of FATE without actually having to play FATE? You want it all packaged in a way that might actually pull some people from the dragon game and it’s ilk? Turns out someone made it. It’s City of Mist.

When we talk about the evolution of trad games in the 2010s, a few groups get brought up consistently. MCG, Free League, Quest, etc. You know what doesn’t but absolutely should? City of Mist. So much more evolutionarily interesting. Trad x FATE x PbtA that somehow actually works.

@momatoes But this entire endeavor should’ve been aborted before it ever started, and that’s not something someone with even extensive lived experience would necessarily know without first consulting a range of professional diagnostic texts to see where it would ultimately lead.

@momatoes This whole episode has really helped me solidify something I’ve been struggling with for some time, honestly, which is that I don’t think lived experience or professional qualification are sufficient to gamify serious topics absent the other, and sometimes not even together.

Like imagine a DM attempting to handle mechanizing transvestic paraphilia (e.g. when cross-dressing is both arousing and distressing to an individual) in any way that isn’t horrifically grotesque, deeply fucked, and unspeakably inappropriate. That doesn’t even break the Top 10…

One of many reasons not to make a DSM-V monster manual or really mechanize it in any rigidly applied way. But also just pointing out that if one were to make a MM out of the DSM-V, it’s not just things like depression and ADHD that you’re contending with. It can get way uglier.

Just to point out a very inside baseball diagnostic psychology thing, vis-à-vis today’s discourse: the DSM-V took a big step back over the past two iterations by much more rigidly defining normative sexuality and by extension paraphilic disorders. 1/

@WeirdRealmsCLE Like was Sony involved with arms manufacturing? Totally. But are NFTs fundamentally a tax haven grift that started getting popular when the IRS began looking into taxing fine art transactions, making them less suitable for criminal money laundering? Absolutely. Take your pick.

@WeirdRealmsCLE Although if we’re taking it in aggregate (i.e. all NFT production and use vs. all major labor music production), I do think there’s a case to be made that the NFT side could be more environmentally damaging overall in time. So participation in it could be ultimately worse.

@WeirdRealmsCLE Neither is great? But for a time one was absolutely the cost of doing business if you wanted to find any kind of financial success and be a career musician. Hypocritical? Yes. But understandable. There’s no cause to the NFT side, though. Perhaps not worse, but less justifiable.
